translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽The Chapter with Kaṇikāra Flowers
The Elder Who Gave a Wood-Apple

analyzed: kaṇikārava jalita  puṇṇa māyā iva candima
translated: Like a flowering kaṇikāra,🔽like the moon on the night of the full moon,
like a flame-tree in bloom,
I saw the Leader of the World.🔽Taking a wood-apple,
I gave it to the Teacher,
to the Worthy One, the Hero,
with faith in my hands.
Thirty-one eons ago,
the fruit I gave then,
I do not know of a bad destination,
this is the fruit of giving fruit.
My defilements are destroyed,
I live without defilements.
Welcome indeed it was,
I have done the Buddha’s bidding.
The four analytical insights,
I have done the Buddha’s bidding.”

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā mātuluṅgaphaladāyako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā mātuluṅgaphaladāyakaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: Thus the elder who gave a wood-apple, the venerable Mātuluṅgaphaladāyaka, recited these verses.
The Elder Who Gave a Wood-Apple’s Birth Story is the sixth.
